Description: Gypsum wall panel relief: Assyrian capture of fortress in Egypt. At the top Assyrians storm the fortress; one tries to set fire to the gate while others undermine walls. Prisoners marched out are recognisable as Nubian soldier of Taharka, wear a single upright feather on their heads; native Egyptians are represented by a group of civilian prisoners with two children on a donkey. Below is a river containing many fish and some crabs.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir Henry Creswicke Rawlinson
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: North Palace (Nineveh), Room M Panel 17
Bibliographic references: Barnett 1976 / Sculptures from the North Palace of Ashurbanipal at Nineveh (668-627 B.C) (p.47, pl.XXXVI)
Hall H R 1928a / Babylonian and Assyrian Sculpture in the British Museum (pl.XL)

Pritchard, J B 1954a / The Ancient Near East in Pictures relating to the Old Testament (fig.10)
Gadd 1936b / The Stones of Assyria: the surviving remains of Assyrian sculpture, their recovery, and their original positions (p.196)
Brunner 1952-53 / Ein assyrischer Relief mit einer ägyptischen Festung (pp.253-62)
Reade 1979b / Ideology and propaganda in Assyrian art: a symposium on ancient empires (fig.8)
Exhibition history: 2018-2019, 8 Nov - 24 Feb, London, BM, I am Ashurbanipal, king of the world, king of Assyria 2022 27 April – 25 July, Paris, Musée du Louvre, Pharaoh of the Two Lands
